title: 109_hr3170
content: The Act is titled the "Livestock Identification and Marketing Opportunities Act". It includes findings related to livestock. The Livestock Identification and Marketing Opportunities Act emphasizes the need for an efficient automated livestock identification system to trace animals quickly and prevent economic losses in the beef industry, estimated at $3 billion due to bovine spongiform encephalopathy in 2003. The Livestock Identification and Marketing Opportunities Act highlights the importance of a flexible livestock identification system using the best available technology, ensuring confidentiality of information, and providing commercial information exchange infrastructure for enhanced marketing opportunities. The Livestock Identification and Marketing Opportunities Act emphasizes the need for a flexible livestock identification system with advanced technology and confidentiality measures. The Livestock Identification Board is established to maintain an electronic livestock identification system that can trace all livestock in the United States within 48 hours of movement from original premises to slaughter, tracking relevant information about each animal. The Livestock Identification Board assigns identification numbers to livestock, records premises and species information, including date of birth and sex, for disease surveillance. Information is centralized in a data system, and official identification technology is determined. The Livestock Identification Board assigns identification numbers to livestock, records premises and species information for disease surveillance. The Board determines the official identification technology to track animals. The Board may prescribe fees and establish a grant program. The Board is composed of 7 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Agriculture. The Livestock Identification Board consists of 7 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Agriculture, including representatives from swine, sheep, goat, and poultry owners, livestock auction market operators, meat processors, and individuals actively engaged in the livestock industry. Additionally, there are 2 non-voting members representing the Department of Agriculture. The Livestock Identification Board has 7 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Agriculture, including representatives from various sectors of the livestock industry. Additionally, there are 2 non-voting members representing the Department of Agriculture. Members serve 3-year terms, with exceptions for initial appointees. The Livestock Identification Board consists of 7 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Agriculture, with 2 non-voting members from the Department of Agriculture. Members serve 3-year terms, with exceptions for initial appointees. The Chairperson is elected by the members, and all appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled for the remainder of the term, and the Board meets regularly. The Livestock Identification Board, consisting of 7 voting members appointed by the Secretary of Agriculture, must hold an initial meeting within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Board shall meet at the call of the Chairperson, with 4 members constituting a quorum. Members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. The Board may appoint staff, enter contracts, and issue rules and regulations. The Livestock Identification Board will implement the livestock identification system by December 31, 2008. They must submit quarterly reports on the system's progress to the Secretary of Agriculture and relevant congressional committees. The reports will include the number of animals tracked and the percentage of each species included in the system. The Board has the authority to issue rules and regulations as needed. The Livestock Identification Board will track the percentage of each animal species in the livestock identification system by dividing the number of animals of a species by the total number in the United States. The Secretary of Agriculture will establish a premise identification system for all premises in the United States within nine months of the enactment of this Act. The system will include a unique premise identification number, owner information, contact details, type of operation, and the date the premise number was assigned. Enforcement and first entry into commerce will also be addressed. The Secretary of Agriculture will verify proper identification of animals upon first entry into commerce under the livestock identification system. Animals not properly identified will be tagged before entering commerce. Additionally, voluntary participation for other animal species is allowed. SEC. 6 allows owners of animals not covered by the livestock identification system to voluntarily participate in tracking. This voluntary tracking does not subject the animals to enforcement actions by the Secretary under section 5. Information obtained through the livestock identification system or premise identification system is exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. Such information is considered privileged, confidential, and not in the public domain, except for limited authorized releases by the Board. The livestock identification system or premise identification system allows for limited release of information if it pertains to a significant threat to livestock, is related to actions under the Act, and is needed for public health and safety reasons as determined by the Secretary of Agriculture. The livestock identification system allows for limited release of information to various entities for purposes such as animal disease surveillance, criminal investigations, national security, and public health. The livestock identification system allows for limited release of information to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for public health protection, and to foreign governments for tracing livestock threatened by disease or pest. Information voluntarily submitted to the Board can be released to livestock owners upon request. Conflict of law situations regarding information disclosure limitations are addressed. This section takes precedence over State law in cases of conflict involving interstate or international commerce. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report on the impact of a livestock identification system within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The report will include lessons learned from pilot programs, an analysis of the economic impact on the livestock industry, and the expected cost of implementing the system. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subsection (f) of section 282 of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 is amended to certify the country of origin. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The Livestock Identification Board is defined as the Board. Livestock includes cattle, swine, sheep, goats, and poultry. A premise is a location that houses animals. The relevant congressional committees are the House Committee on Agriculture and the Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $33,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2008 for this Act.
